channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Guangzhou Activists Sentenced to Jail After Backing Hong Kong Protests
item.description: The activists, Wang Mo and Xie Fengxia, who unfurled a banner as a show of support, are accused of “incitement to subvert state power.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Protesters in Hong Kong on Friday demanding the release of activists in mainland China sentenced to prison after being convicted of “incitement to subvert state power.”

item.title: 13 North Koreans Working Abroad Defect to the South
item.description: The workers at a North Korean government-run restaurant overseas, whose location was not disclosed, were the largest group of defectors in recent years.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jeong Joon-hee, a spokesman for the South Korean Unification Ministry, discussed on Friday the defection of a group of North Koreans.

item.title: In Cambodia, the Ghosts Prefer Dollars
item.description: During the recent Qingming holiday, Cambodians burned a fortune in fake cash to honor their dead, but for many, the local currency just wouldn’t do.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE
item.media:credit: Luc Forsyth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Relatives at the Kambol graveyard on the outskirts of Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, burning fake American currency as an offering to ancestors.

item.title: ‘Calling Sweden. You Will Soon Be Connected to a Random Swede, Somewhere in Sweden’
item.description: A tourism agency has persuaded ordinary Swedes to take calls from curious strangers all over the world.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR
item.media:description: Tourists and a copy of a Viking ship in Stockholm.

item.title: Republicans Seize on Guantánamo Fears in Re-election Races
item.description: With control of the Senate at stake, blue-state Republican incumbents hope the issue will let them reprise Scott Brown’s 2010 win in Massachusetts.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: A detainee paced around a cell block at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba last month.

item.title: Pope Francis, Urging Less Judgment, Signals Path for Divorced on Communion
item.description: Addressing family life, Francis called for priests to welcome single parents, unmarried couples and gay people, lamenting the “severe stress” of modern families.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Pope Francis delivering a message at the end Easter mass at the Vatican on March 27.

item.title: Radicalization of a Belgium Student Turned Bomb Maker Was Invisible
item.description: Najim Laachraoui used skills that could have provided a bright future to build the bombs that, the authorities say, were used in the attacks in Paris and Brussels.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Najim Laachraoui in an undated photograph.

item.title: Sinosphere: Tabloid Editor and Ex-Diplomat Square Off Over China’s Foreign Policy
item.description: Wu Jianmin, a former envoy to France, said Global Times often printed “very extreme articles” and suggested its editor was ignorant of global affairs.
item.dc:creator: OWEN GUO
item.media:description: Wu Jianmin, a former Chinese ambassador to France, in 2013. Mr. Wu criticized the well-known Chinese tabloid Global Times last week, saying it often ran “very extreme articles.”

item.title: Editorial: Financial Secrecy in Panama and Beyond
item.description: While most nations have agreed to share information to root out tax havens, Panama has dragged its feet.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Need to Hide Some Income? You Don’t Have to Go to Panama
item.description: Setting up a shell corporation in the United States is simple — especially in states like Delaware, Wyoming and Nevada.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA COHEN
item.media:credit: Tim Shaffer for The New York Times
item.media:description: This far-from-flashy site in Wilmington, Del., is the legal address of 285,000 businesses.

item.title: Roma Poisoned at U.N. Camps in Kosovo May Get Apology and Compensation
item.description: A panel found that the United Nations compromised the lives and health of inhabitants of the camps, which were built on a toxic wasteland and had high levels of lead.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for the New York Times
item.media:description: A Roma boy living in a United Nations camp contaminated with lead in Kosovo in 2006. Hundreds of Roma families were forced to live in the camps.

item.title: Amazon May Violate India’s New Rules on Foreign E-Commerce
item.description: The government added regulations related to pricing and the sourcing of sales on sites that Amazon and several rivals appear to break.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD and VINDU GOEL
item.media:description: The finale at Amazon India Fashion Week last month in New Delhi. India figures prominently in Amazon’s growth plans.

item.title: Rattled by Attacks, Many Belgians Still Want Nation Split in Two
item.description: The Brussels attacks have shaken Belgium, but many are asking whether the Flemish north would be better off becoming its own country.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professed “soccer hooligans” and left-wing activists clashed at a peaceful rally in Brussels last month, near a shrine to victims of the March 22 terrorist attacks.

item.title: Panama Papers Continue to Shake Leaders, Including Cameron and Putin
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia dismissed the documents as an American plot, Iceland chose new leadership and Britain’s prime minister admitted to profiting from an offshore trust.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Dmitry Astakhov/Sputnik / Kremlin
item.media:description: From left, the cellist Sergei P. Roldugin, Vladimir V. Putin and Dmitry Medvedev at the House of Music in St. Petersburg in 2009.

item.title: European Union to Consider Requiring Visas for U.S. Travelers
item.description: The union is stepping up pressure on the United States to add more European countries to its list of those entitled to visa-free travel.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Dutch Referendum Rejects Trade Deal Between E.U. and Ukraine
item.description: In a nonbinding election, voters in the Netherlands said no to a trade and cooperation pact. All 28 member countries must approve the deal.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Republicans Seize on Guantánamo Fears in Re-election Races
item.description: With control of the Senate at stake, blue-state Republican incumbents hope the issue will let them reprise Scott Brown’s 2010 win in Massachusetts.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: A detainee paced around a cell block at Guantánamo Bay in Cuba last month.

item.title: Ernst Tremmel, Nazi War Crimes Suspect, Dies Days Before Trial
item.description: Mr. Tremmel, a 93-year-old former SS storm trooper who worked at Auschwitz, faced charges of complicity in the killings of at least 1,075 prisoners.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Reinhold Hanning, a former Nazi charged with being an accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people at a concentration camp, arriving at a courthouse in Detmold, Germany, on Wednesday.

item.title: E.C.B. Rules Out Free Money as Antidote to Falling Prices
item.description: “Helicopter money” is not on the table, a top central banker says, but officials at the European Central Bank acknowledge they are worried about deflation.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING
item.media:description: Bundles of euro banknotes. European Central Bank officials do not want to raise expectations that they are about to start carpet-bombing the eurozone with freshly minted bills.

item.title: ISIS Abducts Workers From Cement Factory in Syria
item.description: If confirmed, the mass kidnapping reported by state media would punctuate the Islamic State’s penchant for brazen acts even in the face of recent defeats.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and RICK GLADSTONE
